awd_titl_txt: RUI: Development of Sparsity-inducing Dual Frames and Algorithms with Applications, II
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the ongoing research program of the Principal Investigator in the general area of signal processing. Signal processing is concerned with making signals easier to handle or better in quality.  It is widely used in modern society, such as in cell-phone communications.  In this project, the principal novelties introduced to signal processing are developments of the notion of "sparsity-inducing dual frames" ("sparse duals") and advanced ideas of recovering underlying signals from much smaller "samples" of the signal.  Sparsity-inducing dual frames are a set of signal components used in obtaining the sparsest (the most concise) decomposition of a signal.  The substance of sparse duals lies in the fact that they have the capacity to greatly advance the effectiveness of signal recovery through a small number of samples of a signal.  The objective is to advance the art of new signal-detection techniques.  This study has the potential to impact information technology, ranging from simplified sampling devices to radar systems, commercial imaging techniques, geographic survey, mapping, wireless communication, surveillance systems, medical image requisitions and combinations, and a number of signal requisition applications.

Topics proposed for study include the development of tail-minimization techniques in the sparse-dual-based l-one analysis approach and applications, together with the development of a soft-thresholding-infused null-space tuning algorithm with feedbacks for more effective denoising and signal smoothness.  Several themes will be developed.  One theme aims at directly reducing the tail coefficients of sparse frame expansions.  This is motivated by the observation that the signal recovery error bound is directly proportional to the "tails" of the signal coefficients.  Another theme is to construct sparsity-inducing dual frames that minimize the tail coefficients for a class of s-sparse signals and nearly s-sparse signals.  Such sparse duals are clearly ultimate analysis operators in the analysis approach.  A third theme is designed to understand an equivalent l-one synthesis problem derived from a sparse-dual-based l-one analysis formulation.  The new synthesis problem decouples the product of the sensing matrix and the frame matrix, and the kernel of the new sensing matrix is smaller.  A final theme is aimed at infusing soft thresholding into the iterative "Null Space Tuning Algorithm with Feedbacks" (NST+FB).  The NST+FB algorithm is known to converge in finitely many steps.  The Principal Investigator will enrich the NST+FB algorithm with a soft-thresholding mechanism for enhanced denoising and smoothness, for applications such as image processing and radar imaging.

OUTCOMES (DMS-1615288), Shidong Li, P.I., shidong@sfsu.edu

This project relates to signal processing applications, data sciences and algorithms in artificial intelligence (AI). Signal processing generally refers to making signals easy to handle and/or to possess better quality. Data sciences and AI are studies and use of data to extract meaningful insights for specific purposes such advertising, personal assistance, etc.  They are everywhere seen in our modern society such as cell phone, its Apps, google search engine and ChatGPT system, etc.

In this project, the principal novelties and outcomes that P.I. is able to introduce and contribute are the developments of various advanced theories and algorithms of recovering underlying signals from much smaller "samples" of the signal.  There are both theory and numerical demonstrations.

These are summarized in 22 completed research articles. The followings are some highlights.   

Figure 1 and effectiveness: The energy localization/relocation technique in the form of tail-l1 minimization is proven to be extremely effective comparing with other state-of-the-art signal recovery techniques.  This can be seen from Figure 1 in which the rates of successful signal recovery verses signal sparsity level s are plotted for different methods.  The flatter the curve is further extending to the right, the better the corresponding algorithm is.

Figure 2 and efficiency:   The speedy signal recovery efficiency is demonstrated in Figure 2 by P.I.’s tail-Hadmard parameterization algorithm for the (efficient) implementation of the tail-l1 minimization.

Discovering undiscovered: The P.I. discovered a solution existence phenomenon that was previously known as impossible. In the previous commonly known linear algebra argument, signal recovery is only possible up to the sparsity level S/2 (where S is a physical parameter “spark” of the measurement device).

However, in a more in-depth mathematical measure (probability) argument, the P.I. extends the recovery upbound theory to the sparsity level S (from the widely known S/2).   

Furthermore, the P.I. also proved mathematically traditional l1-minimization-based signal recovery techniques must fail if the sparsity level is greater than S/2. Therefore, most traditional techniques are not capable of recovering signals of sparsity level beyond S/2.  

Yet, the energy relocation techniques in the form of tail-l1 minimization can discover the undiscovered when the sparsity level is beyond S/2 and within S.  See Figure 1 comparing the black l1-min rate of success curve vs the red tail-l1-min curve.  One can see that the l1-min curve comes down and fail before S/2=64/2=32. Yet, tail-l1-min is able to recover signals all the way towards the sparsity level S=64.

Scientific Foundation:  Scientific advances lie also in the understanding of fundamental theory behind the science.  Theoretical analyses are therefore critical in P.I.’s investigations.

The first theoretical establishment is the previously mentioned “discovering undiscovered” mathematical measure theoretical discovery on solution upper bound, and why traditional l1-min techniques are incapable of seeing this. 

One other theoretical establishment by the P.I. is the convergence proof of the NST+FB algorithms, guaranteeing the effective algorithm converges to the exact signal.     

Another theory is the necessary and sufficient tail-NSP condition that shows clear advantages over the previous and widely known NSP condition.   

Yet the other scientific foundation established by the P.I. is the signal recovery guarantee analyses for the energy relocation theories and algorithms.  The P.I. is able to establish theoretically that the probability of successful signal recovery is significantly higher than that of traditional l1-min approaches. 

What is also worth of mentioning is another theoretical advance is that the reconstruction guarantee condition.  The P.I. is able to show that one needs only the tail-NSP (or NSP) condition to prove the reconstruction oracle error bound, without an additional robustness assumption that was always required in the past.  Though published, such a theoretical finding is perhaps still unknown to many scientists. 

Figure 3 and energy relocation in the form of tail-l2 minimization:  The P.I. observes that infusing the energy relocation mechanism in a form of tail-l2 minimization is simultaneously effective and efficient at sparse signal recovery.  Figure 3 demonstrates that the tail-l2-min is actually more effective than the traditional l1-min approach.     Furthermore, the tail-l2-min technique has close form solution in each iteration.  It is therefore exceedingly fast in numerical implementations, particularly for the more practical large systems. 

Summary:  These outcomes can greatly advance the effectiveness of the signal recovery through a small number of "samples" of a signal.  They ought to have a noteworthy impact to information technology ranging from designing simplified sampling devices to designing complexity-reduced imaging techniques, reduced complexity in geographic survey, mapping, wireless communication, multi-sensor/camera surveillance systems, multi-channel medical image requisition and combinations, and a great number of signal requisition applications.
